Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

hashtag#Hiring hashtag#SeniorJavaDeveloper hashtag#AreaDocExchange 🚀 Senior Java Developer (Kafka | AWS Lambda | Spring Boot) 🚀📍 Location: hashtag#INDIAGurugram | 💼 Experience: 5+ Years🔹 About the RoleWe’re looking for a Senior Java Developer to design, build, and optimize scalable backend systems and serverless applications using Kafka, AWS Lambda, Spring Boot, and Terraform. If you’re passionate about real-time data processing and cloud-native development, this is your chance to make an impact!🔹 Key Responsibilities✔ Backend Development: Design & develop high-performance Java/Spring Boot applications.✔ Serverless Architecture: Build & deploy AWS Lambda functions using AWS Java SDK.✔ Real-Time Data Processing: Implement Kafka for event-driven, scalable data pipelines.✔ Infrastructure as Code (IaC): Manage AWS resources using Terraform.✔ Cloud Integration: Optimize and secure AWS-based microservices.✔ Collaboration: Work with cross-functional teams to deliver scalable, resilient systems.🔹 Skills & Qualifications✅ 5+ years of hands-on Java & Spring Boot development.✅ Strong expertise in AWS Lambda, AWS Java SDK, and serverless architectures.✅ Experience with Kafka for real-time event streaming.✅ Proficiency in Terraform (IaC) for AWS resource management.✅ Knowledge of AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, API Gateway, etc.) is a plus.✅ Familiarity with CI/CD pipelines (Jenkins/GitLab).🔹 Why Join Us?🌍 Cutting-Edge Tech Stack | 🚀 High-Impact Projects | 🤝 Collaborative Team Culture📈 Career Growth Opportunities | 🏢 Gurugram 📩 Ready to Elevate Your Career? Apply now or share your resume at 📌 elevsolutions5@gmail.com🗳️Let’s innovate together!☘️hashtag#JavaJobs hashtag#SeniorJavaDeveloper hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#Kafka hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#Terraform hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#Serverless hashtag#TechJobs hashtag#GurugramJobs hashtag#HiringNow hashtag#BackendDeveloper hashtag#Microservices hashtag#AWS

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

hashtag#Hiring hashtag#SeniorJavaDeveloper hashtag#AreaDocExchange 🚀 Senior Java Developer (Kafka | AWS Lambda | Spring Boot) 🚀📍 Location: hashtag#INDIAGurugram | 💼 Experience: 5+ Years🔹 About the RoleWe’re looking for a Senior Java Developer to design, build, and optimize scalable backend systems and serverless applications using Kafka, AWS Lambda, Spring Boot, and Terraform. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Struggling to attract and retain top nonprofit talent? You’re not alone.Hiring in the nonprofit sector has never been easy, but today’s tight labor market makes it even tougher. Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Plus, we discuss how flexible work options and board engagement can help your organization stay competitive.Tune in to this episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne and learn how to build a strong, mission-driven team.hashtag#Nonprofit hashtag#TalentManagement hashtag#HRStrategy hashtag#NonprofitHiring hashtag#KickinItWithCorinne

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Struggling to attract and retain top nonprofit talent? You’re not alone.Hiring in the nonprofit sector has never been easy, but today’s tight labor market makes it even tougher. Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Plus, we discuss how flexible work options and board engagement can help your organization stay competitive.Tune in to this episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne and learn how to build a strong, mission-driven team.hashtag#Nonprofit hashtag#TalentManagement hashtag#HRStrategy hashtag#NonprofitHiring hashtag#KickinItWithCorinne

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Struggling to attract and retain top nonprofit talent? You’re not alone.Hiring in the nonprofit sector has never been easy, but today’s tight labor market makes it even tougher. Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Plus, we discuss how flexible work options and board engagement can help your organization stay competitive.Tune in to this episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne and learn how to build a strong, mission-driven team.hashtag#Nonprofit hashtag#TalentManagement hashtag#HRStrategy hashtag#NonprofitHiring hashtag#KickinItWithCorinne

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Struggling to attract and retain top nonprofit talent? You’re not alone.Hiring in the nonprofit sector has never been easy, but today’s tight labor market makes it even tougher. Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Plus, we discuss how flexible work options and board engagement can help your organization stay competitive.Tune in to this episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne and learn how to build a strong, mission-driven team.hashtag#Nonprofit hashtag#TalentManagement hashtag#HRStrategy hashtag#NonprofitHiring hashtag#KickinItWithCorinne

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Plus, we discuss how flexible work options and board engagement can help your organization stay competitive.Tune in to this episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne and learn how to build a strong, mission-driven team.hashtag#Nonprofit hashtag#TalentManagement hashtag#HRStrategy hashtag#NonprofitHiring hashtag#KickinItWithCorinne

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Struggling to attract and retain top nonprofit talent? You’re not alone.Hiring in the nonprofit sector has never been easy, but today’s tight labor market makes it even tougher. Competition from private companies, budget constraints and grant limitations can make attracting top talent feel like an uphill battle. So how can your nonprofit stand out and bring in the right people?The latest episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne tackles this challenge head-on, sharing creative strategies to help nonprofits compete for candidates without breaking the bank.One of your greatest recruitment tools? Your mission. Many job seekers today want work that means something, and nonprofits are in a unique position to offer that. But passion alone isn’t enough—you need the right HR solutions to attract and retain top talent.We cover innovative staffing solutions like shared services (collaborating with other nonprofits on HR resources), outsourcing key HR functions to experts and using technology and automation to streamline hiring and operations. Plus, we discuss how flexible work options and board engagement can help your organization stay competitive.Tune in to this episode of Kickin’ It With Corinne and learn how to build a strong, mission-driven team.hashtag#Nonprofit hashtag#TalentManagement hashtag#HRStrategy hashtag#NonprofitHiring hashtag#KickinItWithCorinne

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Not all recruiters are the problem.In my previous post, I talked about shady recruiters and companies—especially recruiters. And yes, I often criticize the hiring process.I often write about how hard it is to find a job. How the hiring process can be far from logical. How job searching feels like a long, exhausting marathon.But there's one important thing I want to highlight: I have met some truly great recruiters✨️.They don’t just conduct interviews and send the usual “we went with another candidate” message. They help you understand the market, share valuable insights, and genuinely want candidates to find the right fit.Unfortunately, even the best recruiters can’t create opportunities where none exist. But that doesn’t mean their work is meaningless. I’ve met professionals who are truly passionate about what they do, making the job search feel a little less lonely.🔥I appreciate their work and sincerely hope they continue to succeed—with great candidates, fewer hiring challenges, and maybe even a little less criticism (for example, from me).Recruiters, thank you for everything you do!Have you come across great recruiters in your job search?hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#recruiting hashtag#career hashtag#hiring hashtag#hr
